title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from the Democratic Republic of the Congo engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Democratic Republic of the Congo?
preds:
I am using the current crowd forest of 10% as a baseline. I then increase it by 10% as the current prediction still doesn't factor in the recent outbreak of communal violence between Hema cattle-herders and Lendu farmers in Ituri province. It is estimated that around 160 people were killed in communal clashes between these groups between 7 and 16 June. The security forces don't have the capacity and/or the inclination to prevent an escalation of the crisis. Moreover, around 50,000 were killed in clashes between these groups in the period of 1999-2007 and I believe that this history of deadly clashes makes a serious escalation more likely.
While I think that EWP's statistical model overestimates the risk (31%) of a new outbreak because it is affected by data from the Kivus, which should be discounted, I still increase my forecast by further 5% to account for structural risk factors identified by the EWP's statistical model.  I admit that increasing by 5% and not by 4% or 6% in both cases is a purely arbitrary decision, but I am very new at this forecasting project and I am still trying to find a more constructive way to think about it.  Sources:
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-48676435
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-congo-violence/at-least-161-dead-in-northeast-congo-in-apparent-ethnic-clashes-idUSKCN1TI1FT
https://news.un.org/en/story/2019/06/1040711
ACLED data

Relying on news reports over several years, there are *always* people in the DRC being killed by armed groups. I doubt that 2019 will be an exception; an outbreak of peace seems unlikely, but I suppose possible.

Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007 Other judgments: 
- EWP estimate at 30.9%. [1] It's the highest ranked country in their data base.
- Crowd forecast here is 3%. Inside view: 
- EWP already list one episode in the DRC as an ongoing mass killing: "Insurgent groups in the Kivus intentionally target civilians as part of the ongoing series of conflicts." [2]
- EWP also note that "violence in the Kasai region, which has reportedly included serious abuses by the government and by non-state forces, could be a potential locus of a new mass killing." This seems to be justified. [4] However, I couldn't find new reports of violence since fall of last year which might indicate that things have improved. Those who have returned seem to have sparked another humanitarian crisis though. [5]
- Between 500 and 900 people were killed in ethnic violence in December in Northwestern Congo. [3] A postponed election took place a few days ago, but I couldn't find anything on renewed violence. [6] Overall judgment:
- Crowd forecast is clearly too low. EWP strikes me as a bit too high, given that the situation in Kasai seems to have improved.
- Still, Kasai is a potential cause of another mass killing episode, so is Northwestern Congo apparently.
- Adding in unknown unknowns, this leads me to estimate about 13%. [1] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/democratic-republic-of-congo
[2] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/ongoing-mass-killing
[3] https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-47538851
[4] https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-44613147
[5] https://news.un.org/en/story/2019/03/1034601
[6] https://www.dw.com/en/dr-congo-safety-fears-surround-special-yumbi-vote/a-47953084
